Award.AwardTitle: RI Small: On Robot Motor Capability for Skill Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: Endowing humanoid robots with the ability of skill learning will enable them to be versatile and skillful in performing various tasks. The problem of transferring human skills to humanoid robots raises tremendous research interest in studying human and robot motor skills. Our research aims at developing a quantitative measure of robot motor capability of a humanoid root motor system for the application of transferring human skills to a humanoid robot. An in-depth study of basic intrinsic properties of robot motor capability based on information theory will be performed to derive a pseudo index of motor performance. This pseudo index of motor performance is derived from robot kinematics, dynamics, and control with the speed-accuracy constraint taken into consideration. With the speed-accuracy constraint, the motor performance of a robot is optimized to accomplish a task. The research results demonstrate an increased understanding of robot motor capability that shows the capability and limitation of a robot for learning skills from human demonstration. The project plans to verify the result on an existing humanoid robot. The project results will provide new insights in humanoid robot motor learning and control, and launch a new research direction on human-robot interaction when both humans and robots better know their respective motor capabilities. The broader impacts include incorporation of research results into existing graduate and undergraduate robotics courses, and outreach activities of a weeklong robotics summer camp and a lab open house for high-school students. The research results will be disseminated in professional conferences, workshops and archival journal publications.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focuses on the investigation of methodologies that will improve the motor and cognitive capabilities of humanoid robots to broaden their skills for various collaborative tasks.  The project has achieved the following contributions:

(1) Investigated and developed Extended-Cooperative-Task-Space (ECTS) framework for dual-arm cooperative tasks performed by humanoid robots or human-robot systems [1].  Task specification and performance evaluation were developed for dual-arm collaborative tasks [2]. With the ECTS framework, the motion planning for dual-arm manipulation tasks can be greatly simplified because the operator can focus on high-level descriptions of those tasks instead of planning motion trajectory for each joint of the robot.

(2) Investigated and developed a 3D-point-cloud system for human-pose estimation and the use of feedforward neural networks for its modelling and realization [3,4].  We further associate human actions with human pose estimation to lower the dimensionality of human-pose space in searching human poses.

(3) Investigated and developed a methodology for designing time-dependent controllers that realize walking for both fully actuated and under-actuated bipedal robots. Formal stability analysis was performed on resulting biped robotic system [5,6].

Software (simulation package) and hardware (Hubo-II+ robot and Baxter robots) infrastructure was used for DARPA Robotics Challenge (2013 Trials), student independent projects and teaching as well as outreach activities.  Results were published in professional conferences and archival journals.

Four Ph.D. students and two MS students were graduated with supports from this grant.

 

References:

[1] H. Andy Park and C. S. George Lee, “Extended Cooperative-Task Space for Manipulative Tasks of Humanoid Robots,” Proceedings of 2015 IEEE Int’l Conf. on Robotics and Automation, Seattle, WA, pp. 6088-6093, May 26-30, 2015.

[2] H. Andy Park and C. S. George Lee, “Dual-Arm Coordinated-Motion Task Specification and Performance Evaluation,” Proceedings of 2016 IEEE/RSJ International Conference on Intelligent Robots and Systems, Daejeon, South Korea, pp. 929-936, October 9-14, 2016.

[3] Kai-Chi Chan, Cheng-Kok Koh, and C.S. George Lee, “A 3D-Point-Cloud System for Human-Pose Estimation,” IEEE Trans. on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics, Vol. 44, No. 11, pp. 1486 – 1497, Nov. 2014.

[4] Kai-Chi Chan, Cheng-Kok Koh, and C.S. George Lee, “An Automatic Design of Factors in a Human-Pose-Estimation System using Neural Networks,” IEEE Trans. on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics, Vol. 46, No. 7, pp. 875 – 887, July 2016.

[5] Yan Gu, B. Yao, C. S. G. Lee, “Orbitally Exponential Stabilization of Underactuated Bipedal Walking based on Time-dependent Output Feedback Control,” Proceedings of 2017 American Control Conference (ACC), Seattle, WA, May 24-26, 2017.

[6] Yan Gu, Bin Yao, and C.S. George Lee, “Exponential Stabilization of Fully Actuated Planar Bipedal Robotic Walking,” to appear in ASME Journal of Dynamic Systems, Measurements, and Control.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project focuses on the investigation of methodologies that will improve the motor and cognitive capabilities of humanoid robots to broaden their skills for various collaborative tasks. The project has achieved the following contributions: (1) Investigated and developed Extended-Cooperative-Task-Space (ECTS) framework for dual-arm cooperative tasks performed by humanoid robots or human-robot systems [1]. Task specification and performance evaluation were developed for dual-arm collaborative tasks [2]. With the ECTS framework, the motion planning for dual-arm manipulation tasks can be greatly simplified because the operator can focus on high-level descriptions of those tasks instead of planning motion trajectory for each joint of the robot. (2) Investigated and developed a 3D-point-cloud system for human-pose estimation and the use of feedforward neural networks for its modelling and realization [3,4]. We further associate human actions with human pose estimation to lower the dimensionality of human-pose space in searching human poses. (3) Investigated and developed a methodology for designing time-dependent controllers that realize walking for both fully actuated and under-actuated bipedal robots. Formal stability analysis was performed on resulting biped robotic system [5,6]. Software (simulation package) and hardware (Hubo-II+ robot and Baxter robots) infrastructure was used for DARPA Robotics Challenge (2013 Trials), student independent projects and teaching as well as outreach activities. Results were published in professional conferences and archival journals. Four Ph.D. students and two MS students were graduated with supports from this grant. References: [1] H. Andy Park and C. S.
